title: Slow enum printing in WinDbg

labels.name: A-debuginfo
labels.description: Area: Debugging information in compiled programs (DWARF, PDB, etc.)

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
In a minimal case like:
```Rust
fn main() {
    let foo = vec![Some(1), Some(2), Some(3)];
}
```
Examining `foo` with `dx` takes around a second to print each member of the Vec, which is already pretty slow, but it can get slower based on something seemingly related to the debugee program as a whole, possibly the amount of code or the size of the pdb.

For example, putting `let foo = vec![Some(1), Some(2), Some(3)];` at the start of `main` in a ~2210 LoC program with a 10.1 MB pdb and examining that with WinDbg, it takes around 20 seconds for each member in the Vec.

Extracting out 1 module (a not correct solution for AoC 2022 day 13 part 1) from the previously mentioned program for ~108 LoC and a 2.35 MB pdb, then examining the same `foo` at the start of the program results in around 3 seconds for each member in the Vec.

Rust version:
```
rustc 1.69.0 (84c898d65 2023-04-16)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 84c898d65adf2f39a5a98507f1fe0ce10a2b8dbc
commit-date: 2023-04-16
host: x86_64-pc-windows-msvc
release: 1.69.0
LLVM version: 15.0.7
```

WinDbg version: 10.0.14321.1024
OS: Windows 10 Pro 22H2 19045.2846
CPU: Ryzen 5 3600
